Award.AwardTitle: Approximation and Orthogonality in Sobolev Spaces
Award.AbstractNarration:
This research project is concerned with the study of approximations of functions of several variables by families of simpler, polynomial functions (and related questions) in the setting of Sobolev spaces, which are abstract mathematical function spaces originally developed to study problems in mathematical physics and which are utilized today in a number of scientific computing settings. A truly complex system or problem is often intractable, and we often need to find an approximation that is more manageable. Approximation methods on domains in higher dimensional spaces are good examples of this principle, and they are crucial in many problems in applied mathematics. In contrast to one dimension, many challenging problems in higher dimensions that are of fundamental importance are not resolved. The Principal Investigator will study several problems on approximation and orthogonality in Sobolev spaces that rely on new connections and ideas revealed only recently. The project aims at both theoretical understanding and construction of new approximation methods, and the work has the potential to impact scientific computing, numerical analysis, statistics, and geoscience.

The Principal Investigator will study approximation and orthogonality in Sobolev spaces on regular domains, such as cubes, balls, spheres, and simplexes. The project combines several research topics: approximation theory, Fourier analysis, numerical analysis, and orthogonal polynomials. One of the main problems originates from the area of spectral methods for the numerical solution of partial differential equations. Through recent work of the Principal Investigator and collaborators, it has become increasingly clear that understanding orthogonality in Sobolev spaces is crucial for approximation and computation in Sobolev spaces. This research will be based on recent progress in characterization of best approximation by polynomials on the unit sphere and on the unit ball, in Sobolev orthogonal polynomials, and in spectral approximation. The project is expected to lead to new scientific computational methods and new algorithms.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project studies Approximation and Orthogonality in the Sobolev spaces on regular domains. Polynomial approximation and orthogonal polynomials are fundamental tools in applied mathematics, numeral analysis and scientific computations. They have been used, for example, in numerical solution of ordinary and partial differential equations, such as in spectral method, and they are instrumental in discretizing integrals, or constructing highly accurate numerical integration rules. In this information age, finding new tools for high dimensional problems becomes increasingly more important. This project aims at understanding fundamental questions on approximation and orthogonality on regular domains in high dimension.  

Approximation in Sobolev spaces requires simultaneous approximation (of functions and their derivatives). The problem has been studied in Approximation Theory community and in Spectral Method community, but separately, by ad hoc methods. Only recently it is realized that the correct tool is the Fourier series in Sobolev orthogonal polynomials. It means that we should extend orthogonality from inner product defined by function integrals to orthogonality with respect to an appropriately defined inner product in the Sobolev space (which involve derivatives), and study the Fourier series in these new polynomials. Under this project, PI has found satisfactory solution for several regular domains, such as weighted integrals on the intervals, on the unit ball and on the triangle. The results provide explicit description of Sobolev orthogonal polynomials and constructive numerical algorithms, and establish the best rate of approximation by polynomials in Sobolev spaces in each case. 

One of the essential difficulties turns out to be the impact of the boundary of the domain on the orthogonality. This leads naturally to the study of orthogonal structure on the curves on the plane. Together with S. Olver, PI has constructed explicitly orthogonal polynomials on each quadratic curve on the plane and studied their properties. In particular, interpolation schemes and quadrature rules are established on the quadratic curves and applied on several singular problems in numerical analysis. These results clarify orthogonal structure on quadratic curves and provide new tools for numerical computations. Furthermore, they lead naturally to the problem of approximation and orthogonality on quadratic surfaces or the domain bounded by suchsurfaces, , which turns out to be a fertile new ground of research. 

The problems studied under this project are motivated by questions in numerical analysis and they are mainly multidimensional problems.  The results that we obtained are applicable and computable, and they provide new tools for a variety of problems in areas such as computational harmonic analysis, spectral method for numerical solutions of differential equations, and approximation of singular integrals.
